metadata.case_name: Petitioners in Writ Petitions Nos. 1424 & 1612 of 1973 v. State of Andhra Pradesh

facts.text: The Andhra Pradesh General Sales Tax Act contains four schedules: First Schedule for single point sales tax under section 5(2)(a), Second for single point purchase tax under section 5(2)(b), Third for declared goods under section 6, Fourth for exempted goods under section 8.

Till 1963, Third Schedule had entry 'coconuts'; Fourth Schedule had 'tender coconuts'. Explanation to Third Schedule: 'coconuts' means fresh or dried coconut shelled or unshelled including copra, excluding tender coconuts.
Amending Act XVI of 1963 replaced explanation: 'coconuts' means dried coconuts shelled or unshelled including copra, excluding tender coconuts.

Dealers questioned liability on purchases of watery coconuts; upheld by AP High Court Single Judge in Sri Krishna Coconut Co. v. Comml. Tax Officer (16 STC 511), holding fully grown coconuts with water neither tender nor dried.

Amending Act 18 of 1966: Explanation to Third Schedule: 'coconuts in item 5' means dried coconuts including copra, excluding watery coconuts (item 10 Second Schedule) and tender coconuts (item 9 Fourth Schedule). Item 10 'watery coconuts' added to Second Schedule with explanation including all coconuts other than those in item 5 Third and item 9 Fourth.
AP High Court in Tagoob Mohammad v. Comml. Tax Officer (28 STC 110) held watery coconuts are oilseeds, declared goods under item 6 section 14 Central Sales Tax Act.

Amending Act XII of 1971 (effective 17-4-1971): Omitted item 10 Second Schedule (watery coconuts) retrospectively from 1-8-1963; amended item 5 Third Schedule to 'coconuts of all varieties'; added item 5-A for watery coconuts at specific points and rates for periods from 1-8-1963 to before 1971 Act, with proviso for refund if tax paid on both watery and subsequent coconuts.

Introduced sections 7 (Validation of assessments) and 8 (Revision of assessment on coconuts), validating past assessments, barring refunds except under conditions, allowing reassessment within one year.
Central Sales Tax Act section 14 item (vi) 'oil-seeds' amended by Act LXI of 1972 (1-4-73) to specify 'Coconut i.e. copra excluding tender coconuts (cocos nucifera)'.
Writ petitions filed in AP High Court after 1971 amendments; dismissed by Division Bench (Chief Justice and Justice Lakshmaiah).
Civil appeals by some petitioners and direct writ petitions under Art. 32 to Supreme Court.
Watery coconut becomes dry coconut or copra; State does not argue for taxing same coconut twice.
Rule 45 AP GST Rules requires detailed accounts, bills specifying if tax already paid.
Watery coconuts and dried coconuts are commercially distinct: watery for drinking, cooking, religious uses; dried for oil extraction.

legal_issues.text: Liability to sales tax on watery coconuts under Andhra Pradesh General Sales Tax Act and validity of 1971 amending Act XII, including validation provisions and treatment as distinct from dried coconuts.
Whether 1971 amendment violates section 15 Central Sales Tax Act by double taxation on same commodity.

petitioner_arguments.text: Relied on Bhawani Cotton Mills (20 STC 290) to argue that provision for taxation not justifiable merely because it provides for refund.
Challenged liability based on prior High Court rulings that fully grown watery coconuts not taxable as dried or tender.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Sri Krishna Coconut Co. v. CTO (16 STC 511)

respondent_arguments.text: Watery coconuts and dried coconuts are commercially distinct commodities.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: A. Hajee Abdul Shakoor Co. v. State of Madras (1964) 8 SCR 217; other precedents on distinct stages

respondent_arguments.text: 1971 amendment valid; historical periods in item 5-A reproduce earlier law; Rule 45 safeguards against double tax; does not question watery coconut as oilseed pre-1971.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Rattan Lal Co. v. Assessing Authority (25 STC 136)

court_reasoning.text: Unnecessary to consider if watery coconut is oilseed, as Central amendment post-period and State accepts basis; focuses on 1971 Act validity.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Proviso for refund in item 5-A avoids Bhawani defect; Rattan Lal applicable as stage clear.

court_reasoning.text: Rule 45 ensures no double taxation; dealers include only taxable goods in returns.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Safeguards prevent taxing same goods twice.

court_reasoning.text: Watery and dried coconuts commercially distinct; same commodity at different stages can be taxed differently.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Precedents support treating different stages as distinct articles.

court_reasoning.text: Provision for refund addresses section 15 CST Act contingency; no future difficulty.

holdings.text: 1971 Amending Act XII valid; validates past taxes on watery coconuts; treats watery and dried as distinct for taxation with safeguards.
No violation of section 15 Central Sales Tax Act.

outcome.summary: All writ petitions and civil appeals dismissed. The 1971 amending Act held valid, past taxes validated, watery and dried coconuts treated as distinct with safeguards against double taxation.
outcome.costs: Appellants and writ petitioners to pay costs of State of Andhra Pradesh, one set
